msIdentifier.repository: Perne Library: on long-term deposit at Cambridge University Library

summary.seg:
This manuscript, like many others included in the Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries project was once owned or used by Roger Marchall (c. 1417-1477) Rogerus Marshall (c. 1417-1477) , a doctor and physician to Edward IV. In common with numerous other manuscripts, Marchall added a table of contents to the beginning of the manuscript (f. 7v) as well as rubrics and running headings for some of the treatises in the volume (see e.g., ff. 16r, 72r, 102r, and 170r). Marchall's ownership or use of manuscripts is very well-attested, with forty-five surviving books (including this one) bearing evidence to connect him to them in some way; six others may have been his or accessed by him, and a further twelve are recorded but not traced. Thirteen manuscripts owned or used by Marchall (and another with possible Marchall connections) have been digitised, catalogued and conserved as part of the Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries project:
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 59/153 (Voigts 1995, no. 2)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 98/50 (Voigts 1995, no. 4)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 105/57 (Voigts 1995, no. 5)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 159/209 (Voigts 1995, no. 9)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 178/211 (Voigts 1995, no. 10)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 181/214 (Voigts 1995, no. 11)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 345/620 (Voigts 1995, no. 12)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 373/593 (Voigts 1995, no. 13)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 379/599 (Voigts 1995, no. 14)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 401/623 (Voigts 1995, no. 16)
Cambridge, Peterhouse, MS 95 (Voigts 1995, no. 24)
Cambridge, Peterhouse, MS 222 (Voigts 1995, no. 28)
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.8.31 (Voigts 1995, no. 29)
Cambridge, University Library, MS Add. 9213 (possible Marchall connections) (Voigts 1995, no. 48)

Dr Sarah Gilbert
Project Cataloguer for the Curious Cures Project
Cambridge University Library

References: See L. Voigts, 'A doctor and his books: the manuscripts of Roger Marchall (d. 1477)', in R. Beadle and A. J. Piper (eds.), New science out of old books: studies in manuscripts and early printed books in honour of A.I. Doyle (Aldershot, 1995) pp. 249-314

supportDesc.support: Parchment. This is a composite volume and many of the quire-groups have been tightly cropped to fit the shared dimensions of the volume.

foliation.p: Foliated in the second half of the 20th century, or the first quarter of the 21st century.
foliation.note: Foliated in pencil in the upper outer corner of each recto. The designation [i] verso was assigned to the left pastedown during the preparation of this catalogue record for the Curious Cures project in order to produce a functional record in TEI/XML - this designation will appear in [square brackets] throughout the record.

collation.p:
A composite manuscript, formed of quires from several different original manuscript sources. The collation is as follows:
Quire 18 (ff. [i] - 7; 1st leaf is the left pastedown) |
Quire 28 (ff. 8-15) |
Quires 3-1010 (ff. 16-95)
Quire 116 (ff. 96-101) |
Quires 12-1312 (ff. 102-125)
Quire 1410-3 (126-132; 7th-9th cancelled) |
Quire 158+4 (133-144; 4 leaves added after the 1st)
Quire 168 (ff. 145-152)
Quire 172 (ff. 153-154) |
Quire 186 (ff. 155-160) |
Quire 194 (ff. 161-164) |
Quire 208-3 (165-169; 6th-8th cancelled) |
Quire 2112 (ff. 170-181)
collation.formula: 18 (1st leaf is [i] the left pastedown) | 28 | 3-1010 116 | 12-1312 1410-3 (7th-9th cancelled) | 158+4 (4 leaves added after the 1st 168 172 | 186 | 194 | 208-3 (6th-8th cancelled) | 2112

signatures.p: Some quires have alphabetical designations in a modern hand in the lower outer corner of the first recto of the quire, see e.g., f. 46r marked 'd'.

binding.p: 18th-century binding. Cover is a washed and reused document over thin pasteboards. Five raised bands tangible on spine, but inside the volume there are three clearly visible sewing supports, none in alignment with the tangible bands on the spine. All of the Parts of this manuscript were probably together by the late-15th century, and so the discrepancy between the visible supports inside the manuscript and the tangible supports apparent on the spine may be the result of the 18th century rebinding; for example, it is possible that during the rebinding some of the older sewing were retained and then three newer supports added and laced into the new binding. A description of some of the contents of the volume are written in ink on the spine: 'Ordo Baptizandi et Sponsalium'; a faded list of the contents of the volume is present below, but is now illegible. The shelfmark '222' present on the spine in pencil.

Folio [i], the present left pastedown is the verso of the first leaf of the first quire and contains the following inscriptions:
'James Nº 200' in ink, which refers to this item in the Ecloga Oxonio-Cantabrigiensis by Thomas James (1600)
'M R James 222' in pencil, which refers to this item in A Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in the Library of Peterhouse by M. R. James (1899)
The right pastedown is a paper leaf bearing a purple Peterhouse library stamp.

history.provenance: All parts of this manuscript were probably together by the late 15th century. There is a list of the contents of the volume on f. 7v, the final leaf of Part 1, in the hand of Roger Marchall (see Acquisition) that refers to texts in Parts 2, 3, 4, and 9.
history.acquisition: Probably given to Peterhouse by Roger Marchall (c. 1417-1477) Rogerus Marshall -1477 , physician to Edward IV, who gave several other scientific and medical books to the College. Marchall added a partial list of the contents of the volume to f. 7v and supplied titles to texts beginning on ff. 16r, 72r, 102r, and 170r. A list of Marchall's donations to the College is now preserved with the general inventory of the books belonging to the College, in a document now known as Cambridge, Peterhouse Archives, Registrum Vetus (printed in CBMLC 10 as part of UC48). Marchall's donations are recorded in his hand on an inserted slip in the Registrum Vetus, now p. 22 and number twelve items pledged by Marchall to the College; Peterhouse MS 222 is probably item 'ix' on that list described as a 'Phisica plinii' (UC48.393). Marchall as a book owner and donor is discussed in Voigts, 'A doctor and his books', and Peterhouse MS 222 is no. 28 in Voigts' list of manuscripts associated with Marchall. L. Voigts, 'A doctor and his books: the manuscripts of Roger Marchall (d. 1477)', in R. Beadle and A. J. Piper (eds.), New science out of old books: studies in manuscripts and early printed books in honour of A.I. Doyle (Aldershot, 1995) pp. 249-314 CBMLC 10 - UC48.393

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws substantially on R. M. Thomson, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts in the Library of Peterhouse, Cambridge (Woodbridge, 2016). Readers of this record are strongly encouraged to consult Thomson's Catalogue for further information. This catalogue entry also draws on: M. R. James, A descriptive catalogue of the manuscripts in the library of Peterhouse (Cambridge, 1899); CBMLC 10; L. Voigts, 'A doctor and his books: the manuscripts of Roger Marchall (d. 1477)', in R. Beadle and A. J. Piper (eds.), New science out of old books: studies in manuscripts and early printed books in honour of A.I. Doyle (Aldershot, 1995) pp. 249-314; and unpublished notes made by Dr Debby Banham in 1999 and 2000 as part of a survey of medical manuscripts in Cambridge.

availability.p: Researchers should note that Peterhouse's western European medieval manuscripts are housed at Cambridge University Library (CUL). Scholars who wish to consult Peterhouse manuscripts should contact the Manuscripts Reading Room at CUL to arrange their visit; all CUL admissions procedures will apply. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library. For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

custodialHist.p: Recorded as Peterhouse no. 200 in the Ecloga Oxonio-Cantabrigiensis by Thomas James (1600).

msItem.title: Fragment of an liturgical manuscript including the liturgical forms for baptism and marriage
msItem.incipit: [i] (left pastedown) tizo te . N . nomine patribus etc . Modo supradicto scilicet continua ratione
msItem.explicit: 7v qui trinus est in numero et unus est in nomine. Amen
msItem.finalRubric: 7v Hiis peractis aspergat eos aqua benedicta et discedat et dimittat eos in pace
msItem.note: Contains liturgical forms for baptism and marriage, with the vows given in English.
In the rubricated text on f. 6r there is a reference to a papal decree on marriage dated M.C.C.C.XXI (1321).

msItem.title: Partial list of the contents of the volume written before 1477
msItem.author: Roger Marchall (d. 1477)
msItem.note:
Partial list of the contents of the volume by Roger Marchall with a further addition recording the presence of the 'Canonis Avicennae' in a later hand. Full transcription, numbering Marchall's:
Contenta in hoc volumine sunt ista .
1. Tractatus de interpretacione sompniorum secundum danielem prophetam
2. Breuiarius plinii secundi iunioris
3. Excerpta de libro naturalis historie plinii predicti
4. Tractatus Augustini de spiritu et anima
5. Macer de virtutibus herbarum . specierum mineralium . etc
6. Anothomia Galieni
Liber 3us Canonis Avicennae

collation.p: One quire of 8 leaves, the first leaf stuck down and used as the left pastedown.
Quire 18 (1st leaf is [i] the left pastedown; ff. [i], 1-7)

signatures.p: No leaf signatures particular to this Part.
No quire signatures particular to this Part.

catchwords.seg: No catchwords particular to this Part.

supportDesc.condition: Leaves have occasional stains and some text illegible due to rubbing.

p.seg: Ruled in single-column format, frame and lines. Ruled in ink, 27 lines to the page and written below top line.

handNote.p: Written in a northern European textura quadrata.

decoNote.p: Instructions for decorative initials in their unfilled spaces.
Spaces for unfilled decorative initials throughout.

note.p: Peterhouse stamp in purple ink on f. 1r.

origin.origDate: Copied in the 14th century, after 1321. On f. 6r in the rubric de secundis nuptiis there is a reference to a papal decision of 1321, so the main text must have been copied after that date: 'et sciendum est quia ista questio discussa erat determinata in sacro palacio domini pape. Anno domini M.C.C.C.XXI'.
origin.origPlace: Probably copied in England. The liturgical form of the marriage ceremony presented in this volume includes the vows in Middle English in the same hand as the Latin text, so this part of the volume was almost certainly copied in England.

msItem.title: Somniale danielis with prologue [Latin]
msItem.incipit: 8r Cum in ueteri testamento

decoDesc.decoNote: Red and blue line-fillers at the end of minor divisions of the text wherever necessary to maintain the appearance of a 'justified' mise-en-page.

note.p: On f. 9r, '3' with a medieval -us abbreviation (i.e. 'tertius'), in ink in the upper margin.

msItem.author: Avicenna (980–1037)
msItem.incipit: 133r Oportet in primis ut ille qui laborat in conseruando sanitatem oculi
msItem.note: Thomson records that this epitome covers Fen3:Tract2:C5 - Fen10:Tract5:C5

msItem.author: Joannes Hispalensis (trans.) (active 12th century)

msItem.note: The word 'hereford' in the same ink and by the same scribe directly below the final line of this text.

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.note: Several personal names mentioned in the medical recipes.

msItem.title: Experimenta dietarum particularium
msItem.incipit: 144r Contra diuersas passiones spiritualium . Ad mundificacionem pectoris et pulmonis ius de faruba tritici
msItem.note: This does not appear to be an extract from a similarly named work by Isaac Israeli.

msItem.title: Micrologus
msItem.author: Richardus Anglicus ( –1252)
msItem.incipit: 145v Acutarum egritudinum alia est terciana
msItem.note:
Note in the lower margin of f. 146r in a red wavy frame: Micrologus Ricardi magne laudis sed maioris efficacie de causis signis et curis frequenciorum et curabilium morborum, followed by 4 lines of verse: Prologus . Sicut odor nardi spirabit sermo Ricardi
Splendet micrologi lux quasi flamma rogi
Ars prius insurget in causam que magis urget
Dampnaque maiora releuet prius hincque minora.
The first two lines of this poem can also be found in London, British Library, MS Sloane 3282
In the lower marin of f. 150v a note: Hoc solo experimento curauit magr. R. quendam cui nulli medicorum poterant subuenire. etc

listBibl.bibl: See Thorndike, 'Latin Manuscripts of Works by Rasis at the Bibliotheque Nationale, Paris', Bulletin of the History of Medicine, 32 (1958), 54-67, esp. p. 65 for a discussion of the Sloane manuscript.

note.p:
Full transcription reproduced from M. R. James, Catalogue:
Au si uerement si cum deu dit 7 fit . Au si uerement cum deu dit
7 fit bien . Au si uerement garice cest home .I. de cancre
7 de rancle de feste 7 de farcine e de uermine. mort ceit la rancle
emort ceit le chancre . mort ceit le feste ele farcine
e la uermine . etute maladies ke uus tinent . Io te con
iur . Ke acest hume male ne facet . en un de per
et fiȝ e sauyne espirit .+. bibat paciens ap....
Charm is written in the lower margin, the last portion of the text lost to trimming.

listBibl.bibl: R. J. Dean, and M. B. M. Boulton, Anglo-Norman Literature: A Guide to Texts and Manuscripts, Anglo-Norman Text Society Occasional Publications Series, 3 (London: Anglo-Norman Text Society, 1999), no. 440

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.note: The last recipe is attributed to 'Magistri Nicole de Derleng', identified by Thomson as Master Nicholas de Derlega (active c. 1174-1215). See Thomson, Catalogue for more information on de Derlega.

msItem.note: The incipit for this text is close to the opening of the Circa instans.

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.note: Recipes in several 13th century hands, one recipe attributed to a 'Wendofer' or 'Wendover', possibly Richardus Anglicus Richardus Anglicus , also known as Richard of Wendover, a physician active in the first half of the 13th century who served Pope Gregory IX for some of his career and later became a canon of St Pauls.

supportDesc.condition: Some text lost to trimming. Some text in light brown ink on f. 163v is difficult to read.

p.seg: Folios 162v-163v ruled in pencil, frame and lines. Ruled in double-column format, 60-61 lines to the column and written below top line. All other leaves in this Part have an informal layout.

handNote.p: Main texts written in cramped and informal northern European textalis libraria by several scribes. Annotations added by several further scribes writing contemporary and later scripts.

decoNote.p: No notable decoration in this Part.

origin.origDate: Written in the 13th Century, probably in the first half, with later additions.
origin.note: The larger texts in this part are written in styles of informal textualis libraria that are of English aspect, but the medical recipes in Flemish mean that an origin in Flanders cannot be entirely discounted.

msItem.title: De spiritu et anima
msItem.author: pseudo-Augustine
msItem.incipit: 165r Quoniam dictum est mihi ut me ipsum cognoscam
msItem.finalRubric: 169r Explicit tractatus de spiritu et anima

msItem.title: De cognitione uera uitae
msItem.author: pseudo-Augustine
msItem.incipit: 169r Sapientia Dei que os muti apparuit
msItem.explicit: 169r quam ad presens presentium presento scrutinio
msItem.note: Also in Durham, Cathedral Library, MS B.II.20, ff. 106v-111r

msItem.title: Theological notes
msItem.note: In two hands.

collation.p:
Originally a quire of 8 leaves:
Quire 208-3 (6th-8th cancelled; ff. 165-169)

signatures.p: No leaf signatures particular to this Part.
No quire signatures particular to this Part.

catchwords.seg: No catchwords particular to this Part.

supportDesc.condition: Minor loss of text to trimming on f. 169v. Red pigment used for initials and rubrication very powdery and friable, and has become very smudged.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and lines. Ruled in double-column format, typically 65 lines to the column and written below top line.

handNote.p: Main text is written in a northern textualis libraria.
Shorter texts on f. 169v written in northern textualis libraria by two different scribes.

decoNote.p: Red and blue puzzle initial at the opening of the main text (f. 165r. Flourished initials (red initials, blue flourishing) at minor divisions of the text; blue flourishing stops at f. 167v.

msItem.title: De anatomia uiuorum [Latin]
msItem.author: Galen
msItem.incipit: 170r Medicorum anathomicos necesse est precognoscere
msItem.explicit: 181v ad nutrimentum cordis et ad generationem

note.p: Title in the hand of Roger Marchall added to the upper margin of f. 170r
Text preceeded by a list of capitula.

listBibl.bibl: Printed Lyon (1515)

signatures.p: No leaf signatures particular to this Part.
No quire signatures particular to this Part.

catchwords.seg: No catchwords particular to this Part.

supportDesc.condition: Some marginal annotations lost to trimming.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and lines. Ruled in double-column format, typically 51 lines to the column, written below top line.

handNote.p: Written in a northern European textualis rotunda.
Some annotations added in an anglicana hand.

decoNote.p: Plain 'lombardic' initial 'M' at the opening of the text.
Instruction letters for minor initials in their unfilled spaces throughout.
Unfilled spaces for minor initials throughout.
